translated: Stories of Petas🔽The Shorter Section
The Peta with a Discolored Body
“Standing in the sky,

original: Duggandho pūti vāyasi;🔽Mukhañca te kimayo pūtigandhaṁ,
analyzed: duggandhaḥ pūti vāyasi  mukham ca te kim ayaḥ pūti gandha
translated: stinking, rotting,🔽and your mouth full of maggots, stinking,
what action did you previously take?
Then, taking a knife,
you repeatedly cut yourself,
and after smearing yourself with the flesh,

analyzed: okkantanti punappuna  kim nu kāyena vācāya
translated: you repeatedly cut yourself.
What bad action was done by body, speech, or mind?
By the ripening of what action
do you experience this suffering?”
“In the delightful city of Rājagaha,
in the delightful Giribbaja,
I was a lord of wealth and grain,
well-honored, dear sir.
This was my wife,
and my daughter and daughter-in-law;
they brought garlands, blue lotuses,
and ointments for the head.
When they were taking them to the shrine, I stopped them,
that bad action was done by me.
Eighty-six thousand🔽we each experience

analyzed: mayam paccatta vedanā  thūpa pūjam vivaṇṇetvā
translated: by disparaging the worship of the shrine,
we will return to a terrible hell.
Those who, in the worship of the shrine,
the Great Sage, the Worthy One,
they reveal the danger,
so one should separate from them.
And see these coming,
wearing garlands and ornaments;
they experience the results of garlands,
prosperous and famous.🔽Having seen that wonder,

analyzed: tat ca disvānaḥ acchera  abbhutam loma hasana
translated: that marvel that makes one’s hair stand on end,
the wise pay homage,
they worship that Great Sage.🔽So I, having gone from here,

original: Sohaṁ nūna ito gantvā,🔽yoniṁ laddhāna mānusiṁ;
analyzed: sā uham nūnar itas gantvā  yonim laddhāna mā anusi
translated: having obtained a human birth,
I will make offerings to the Shrine,

original: appamatto punappunan”ti.🔽Dhātuvivaṇṇapetavatthu dasamaṁ.🔽Cūḷavaggo tatiyo.🔽Tassuddānaṁ🔽Abhijjamāno kuṇḍiyo,🔽rathakārī bhusena ca;🔽Kumāro gaṇikā ceva,🔽dve luddā piṭṭhipūjanā;
analyzed: appamattaḥ punappunanti  dhātu vivaṇṇa peta vatthu dasama  cūḷa vaggo tatiyo  tassa uddāna  abhijjamānaḥ kuṇḍiyaḥ  rathakārī bhusena ca  kumāraḥ gaṇikā ca iva  dve luddā piṭṭhipūjanā
translated: mindful, again and again.”
